article.title: Molecular Muscle Experiment: Hardware and Operational Lessons for Future Astrobiology Space Experiments
article.abstract: Biology experiments in space seek to increase our understanding of what happens to life beyond Earth and how we can safely send life beyond Earth.

sections.introduction: Space is an extreme environment in which humans have been routinely living and working for more than 20 years, and ambitions remain to live and work further beyond Earth.
sections.methods: The C. elegans strain PD55 (ccIs55 (unc-54::lacZ) V) was used for development and testing phases of this study.
sections.results: We evaluated three culture bags based on past use in C. elegans flight experiments.
sections.discussion: The desired culture bag and EC hardware used in the past were not available for use with MME.

article.insights_summary: The Molecular Muscle Experiment provides a contemporary example of the challenges faced by researchers conducting C. elegans experiments onboard the International Space Station.
article.acknowledgments: The authors would like to thank the UK Space Agency, ESA, JAXA, and BIOTESC for their support of the Molecular Muscle Experiment.
